title: Entrain ligand-trajectory analysis from a Seurat object
text: download developing mouse brain atlas dataset gestation day 10/11. following code block downloads .gz file, decompresses , converts Seurat object analysis. Entrain relies NicheNet database ligand-receptor-gene networks prior knowledge needed make conclusions environmentally-influenced trajectories. genes pre-converted original human genes mouse orthologs.
code: options(timeout=3600) #download.file("https://zenodo.org/record/7233173/files/Manno_E10_E11.rds", "../data/Manno_E10_E11.rds") obj <- readRDS("../data/Manno_E10_E11.rds") lr_network_mm <- readRDS(url("https://zenodo.org/record/7233173/files/lr_network_mm.rds")) #  ligand_target_matrix_mm <- readRDS(url("https://zenodo.org/record/7233173/files/ligand_target_matrix_mm.rds"))

title: Entrain ligand-trajectory analysis from a Seurat object
text: data consists cells developing mouse brain day 10 gestation. comprises population neuroblasts rapidly differentiating neurons (cells going analyse), well complex microenvironment made cells endoderm, mesoderm, fibroblastic, blood, immune compartments.
code: n_clusters <- obj@meta.data$Class %>% unique() %>% length() cols = Seurat::DiscretePalette(n = n_clusters, palette = "alphabet2") DimPlot(obj, group.by = "Class", cols=cols)

what: Run Entrain from a fresh Seurat object.
title: Entrain ligand-trajectory analysis from a Seurat object
text: Entrain fully integrates Monocle3 package learn trajectories. steps Monocle, well Entrain analysis, encapsulated interactive workflow function get_traj_ligands_monocle(). function launches three main interactive steps require input : 1. Call Monocle3 learn trajectory paths. require select ‘root’ cell node. cases, choose cells correspond precursor/progenitor cells system. 2. Second, select cell clusters corresponding microenvironment. 3. Third, select trajectory branches wish analyze.
code: obj_entr<-get_traj_ligands_monocle(obj,                                    sender_cluster_key = "Class",                                    lr_network = lr_network_mm, ligand_target_matrix=ligand_target_matrix_mm)

what: Run Entrain on a Monocle trajectory that you have previously generated.
title: Entrain ligand-trajectory analysis from a Seurat object
text: already pre-generated trajectory generated monocle3 package, Entrain allows start dataset instead re-running process. pre-generated trajectory monocle3::learn_graph() monocle3::order_cells() called already, passed argument get_traj_ligands_monocle(..., cds = monocle_cds)
code: obj_entr<-get_traj_ligands_monocle(obj, cds = monocle_cds,                                    sender_cluster_key = "Class",                                    lr_network = lr_network_mm, ligand_target_matrix=ligand_target_matrix_mm)

title: Entrain ligand-trajectory analysis from a Seurat object
text: useful running compute cluster without GUI. , first plot Monocle results order identify trajectory branches ’d like analyze. can see Monocle captured spurious trajectories well potentially biological ones. Entrain allows us analyze trajectories confident ; example can confident neuroblast differentiation trajectory bounded nodes Y_5 Y_27. also label radial glial cells node Y_7 root cells, setting root_pr_nodes = "Y_7"
code: monocle_cds <- as.cell_data_set(obj) monocle_cds <- monocle3::preprocess_cds(cds = monocle_cds, num_dim = 10) monocle_cds <- monocle3::reduce_dimension(cds = monocle_cds) monocle_cds <- monocle3::cluster_cells(cds = monocle_cds, reduction_method = "UMAP") monocle_cds <- monocle3::learn_graph(monocle_cds,                                      use_partition = TRUE,                                      close_loop = FALSE,                                      learn_graph_control = list(                                          minimal_branch_len = 5,                                          ncenter = 50))  node_coords <- monocle_cds@principal_graph_aux$UMAP$dp_mst %>% t() %>% as.data.frame() %>%     mutate(node = rownames(.)) %>% stats::setNames(c("x", "y", "node")) monocle3::plot_cells(monocle_cds, color_cells_by="Class") +     geom_point(data = node_coords, aes(x=x, y=y)) +     geom_text(data = node_coords, aes(x=x, y=y, label=node)) obj_entr <- get_traj_ligands_monocle(obj, cds = monocle_cds,                                    sender_cluster_names = c("Blood", "Endoderm", "Fibroblast",                                                               "Immune", "Mesoderm"),                                    sender_cluster_key = "Class",                                    root_pr_nodes = "Y_7",                                    path_nodes = c("Y_5", "Y_27"),                                    lr_network=lr_network_mm, ligand_target_matrix=ligand_target_matrix_mm)

title: Entrain ligand-trajectory analysis from a Seurat object
text: can visualize top ranked ligands glance following function, replacing “celltype” relevant column name obj@meta.data  suggests number ligands responsible B cell osteoblast maturation processes. well-established literature key drivers cell differentiation. ligands relatively low expression, difficult pick standard ligand-receptor analysis compared strongly expressed, less biologically impactful ligands. NicheNet unable detect ligands using default parameters. bit threshold tuning, NicheNet fares better still fails include ligands top 5.
code: plot_ligand_trajectories(obj_entr, color_cells_by = "pseudotime", group_label_size=3) ## Cells aren't colored in a way that allows them to be grouped.

title: Entrain ligand-trajectory analysis from a Seurat object
text: can visualize invididual ligand-gene relationships contributing trajectory dynamics. data extracted underlying NicheNet database Entrain uses fitting. can visualize top covarying genes trajectory, including genes influenced extracellular signaling.
code: paths <- obj_entr@misc$entrain$paths %>% names() plot_lig<-plot_ligand_targets(obj_entr, path=paths[1], ligand_target_matrix = ligand_target_matrix_mm) plot_genes<-plot_covarying_genes_scatter(obj_entr, path=paths[1], color_key="Class", n_top_genes = 10) plot_genes

title: Entrain ligand-trajectory analysis from a Seurat object
text: Trajectory branches represent continuum states, may comprise varying degrees environmental dependence along continuum. can visualize environmental influence occurring continuum generate hypotheses cell states less prone environmental influence. influence analysis suggests region strongly influenced environment around border neuroblast neuron cell type label.
code: obj_entr<-cellwise_influences(obj_entr,                               ligand_target_matrix=ligand_target_matrix_mm,                               step_size=0.10,                               window_pct=0.30,                               n_top_ligands=5)

title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: document outlines basic Entrain analysis starting scvelo anndata object pre-calculated velocities. end document, identify ligands driving velocities data. ### Prior knowledge required 1. reasonable idea cell clusters comprise ‘niche’, ligand-expressing cells, dataset. 2. .h5ad object produced scvelo contains velocity data.
code: library("Seurat"); library("SeuratWrappers");library("reticulate"); library("dplyr") library("entrain") ## ℹ Loading entrain ## Warning: replacing previous import 'DT::JS' by 'Seurat::JS' when loading ## 'entrain' ## Warning: replacing previous import 'DT::dataTableOutput' by ## 'shiny::dataTableOutput' when loading 'entrain' ## Warning: replacing previous import 'DT::renderDataTable' by ## 'shiny::renderDataTable' when loading 'entrain'

title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: RNA velocity natively done python, workflow involves calling python scripts R process anndata object. functionality available reticulate package. recommend using conda setup python environment contains required package velocity analysis.
code: # reticulate::conda_create("r-reticulate-sc") # reticulate::conda_install("r-reticulate-sc", "scanpy", "leidenalg", "python-igraph", "adjustText", channel="conda-forge") # reticulate::conda_install("r-reticulate-sc", "scvelo", channel="bioconda") #scvelo not on default conda.  # point to a conda installation that contains scanpy, scvelo, and anndata. reticulate::use_condaenv("r-reticulate-sc")

title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: download developing mouse brain atlas dataset gestation day 10/11. dataset contains RNA expression RNA velocities needed analysis. following code block downloads .gz file, decompresses , converts Seurat object analysis. Entrain relies NicheNet database ligand-receptor-gene networks prior knowledge needed make conclusions environmentally-influenced trajectories. genes pre-converted original human genes mouse orthologs.
code: library("SeuratDisk") options(timeout=3600) h5ad_path <- "Manno_E10_E11.h5ad" download.file("https://zenodo.org/record/7233173/files/Manno_E10_E11.h5ad.gz", "Manno_E10_E11.h5ad.gz") system("gunzip Manno_E10_E11.h5ad.gz") Convert("manno_entrain.h5ad", dest = "h5seurat", overwrite = FALSE, verbose = TRUE) obj <- LoadH5Seurat("Manno_E10_E11.h5seurat", assays="RNA") lr_network_mm <- readRDS(url("https://zenodo.org/record/7233173/files/lr_network_mm.rds")) # ligand_target_matrix_mm <- readRDS(url("https://zenodo.org/record/7233173/files/ligand_target_matrix_mm.rds"))

title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: data consists cells developing mouse brain day 10 gestation. comprises population neuroblasts rapidly differentiating neurons (cells going analyse), well complex microenvironment made cells endoderm, mesoderm, fibroblastic, blood, immune compartments.
code: n_clusters <- obj@meta.data$Class %>% unique() %>% length() cols = Seurat::DiscretePalette(n = n_clusters, palette = "alphabet2") DimPlot(obj, group.by = "Class", cols=cols)

what: Run Entrain from a velocity anndata object.
title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: Entrain fully integrates scvelo package velocity analysis. 3 main steps workflow:

what: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: First, cluster velocities groups similar velocity dynamics. resultant clusters entirely different entity usual cell type annotation. clusters derived velocity matrix, instead RNA expression matrix. consequence cells celltype cluster may necessarily velocity cluster. Unlike trajectory analysis Monocle, require prior information root cell. can see velocity clusters roughly, exactly, correspond cell type clusters, indicating velocities moderately correlated cell type.
code: adata <- entrain_cluster_velocities(h5ad_path, resolution=0.1)

what: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: Step 2. wrapper run scvelo’s recover_dynamics function rank genes based fit-likelihoods, measure gene’s fit RNA velocity ODE model. Higher values denote confidence velocity. Step 3. Run Entrain analysis likelihoods cluster--cluster basis. Steps 2 3 encapsulated single function entrain_velocity. also save resulting .h5ad object plotting results afterwards.
code: sender_cluster_names <- c("Blood", "Fibroblast", "Immune", "Mesoderm") Idents(obj) <- "Class" save_adata =  "manno_entrain_result.h5ad" obj_v <- entrain_velocity(receiver_obj = obj,                           adata = adata,                           save_adata = save_adata,                           velocity_cluster_key = "vcluster",                           sender_cluster_key = "Class",                           sender_clusters = sender_cluster_names,                           num_top_genes = 500L,                           lr_network = lr_network_mm,                           num_jobs=16L,                           ligand_target_matrix = ligand_target_matrix_mm)

title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: can visualize top ranked ligands glance following function, replacing “vcluster” relevant velocity cluster column name adata.obs.
code: plot_velocity_ligands(adata=save_adata,                       color='dimgrey',                       alpha=0.10,                       density=3,                       arrow_size = 1.0,                       linewidth_scale=2,                       vector_type="stream",                       velocity_cluster_key = "vcluster",                       cell_palette="dimgrey",                       size=100,                       velocity_cluster_palette = "gnuplot",                       label_fontsize = 15,                       top_n_ligands = 5L,                       figsize = c(10,10),                       plot_output_path = "manno_entrain.png")

what: {r Plot velocity eval, } # save_adata =  "../data/manno_entrain.h5ad" # plot_velocity_ligands(adata=save_adata, #                       color='dimgrey', #                       alpha=0.10, #                       density=3, #                       arrow_size = 1.0, #                       linewidth_scale=2, #                       vector_type="stream", #                       velocity_cluster_key = "vcluster", #                       cell_palette="dimgrey", #                       size=100, #                       velocity_cluster_palette = "gnuplot", #                       label_fontsize = 15, #                       top_n_ligands = 5L, #                       figsize = c(10,10), #                       plot_output_path = "manno_entrain.png") #
title: Entrain ligand-velocity analysis from an scvelo anndata object.
text: Entrain Velocity Results suggests number ligands responsible neurogenic differentiation processes. well-established literature key drivers cell differentiation.
code: reticulate::use_condaenv("r-reticulate-sc") save_adata =  "../data/manno_entrain.h5ad" reticulate::source_python(system.file("python/entrain_scvelo.py", package = "entrain")) #plot_velocity_ligands_python(adata=save_adata)

code: weighted_networks <- readRDS(url("https://zenodo.org/record/7233173/files/weighted_networks_mm.rds")) library("circlize") ## ======================================== ## circlize version 0.4.15 ## CRAN page: https://cran.r-project.org/package=circlize ## Github page: https://github.com/jokergoo/circlize ## Documentation: https://jokergoo.github.io/circlize_book/book/ ##  ## If you use it in published research, please cite: ## Gu, Z. circlize implements and enhances circular visualization ##   in R. Bioinformatics 2014. ##  ## This message can be suppressed by: ##   suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(circlize)) ## ======================================== draw_entrain_circos(obj = obj_v,                     vcluster= "vcluster1",                     lr_network = lr_network_mm,                     weighted_networks = weighted_networks) ## Warning in RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(length(ligand_types), palette): minimal value for n is 3, returning requested palette with 3 different levels draw_entrain_circos(obj = obj_v,                     vcluster= "vcluster0",                     lr_network = lr_network_mm,                     weighted_networks = weighted_networks) ## Warning in RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(length(ligand_types), palette): minimal value for n is 3, returning requested palette with 3 different levels draw_entrain_circos(obj = obj_v,                     vcluster= "vcluster3",                     lr_network = lr_network_mm,                     weighted_networks = weighted_networks)

what: I have low or negative variance explained, but the output ligands align well with our knowledge about the system!
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: ligand importance relative value, indicate output ligands responsible small subset variance data e.g. small selection genes, majority gene expression influenced environment. gene expression variance cell-intrinsic, lead overall negative variance explained ligands still influence small number (potentially important) genes. knowing , negative variance explained mean ligands automatically wrong. Rather, means , across trajectory, variance attributable cell-intrinsic mechanisms attributable environment.

text: cds CDS object subsetted. reduction_method reduction method plot choosing cells. Currently "UMAP" supported. starting_pr_node NULL, string name starting principal node used. can see principal nodes dataset using plot_cells label_principal_points = TRUE. ending_pr_nodes NULL, one strings name(s) ending principal node(s) used. can see principal nodes dataset using plot_cells label_principal_points = TRUE. return_list Logical, return list cells instead subsetted CDS object. clear_cds Logical, clear CDS slots returning. clearing cds, re-run processing preprocess_cds(), ... Default TRUE.

title: Choose cells along the path of a principal graph. Modified from Monocle3 function choose_graph_segments to allow for selection of multiple branches and zooming in. — choose_path

title: Cluster the velocity matrix — entrain_cluster_velocities
text: adata anndata file containing velocities. velocity_cluster_key Column name cluster labels metadata adata_clustered. Can calculated manually scvelo scvelo.tl.velocity_clusters(). resolution Optional argument defining resolution velocity clustering. Default 0.05. save_adata Optional. Filename anndata object write results . given NULL, anndata saved. Recommended want re-run continue analysis scanpy/scvelo. plot_file Plot file name. Default "velocity_clusters.png". obj seurat object

title: Cluster the velocity matrix — entrain_cluster_velocities
text: Anndata object velocity clusters denoted adata.obs.<velocity_cluster_key>

what: Identify ligands responsible for observed velocity vectors. — entrain_velocity
title: Identify ligands responsible for observed velocity vectors. — entrain_velocity
text: Given anndata object containing clustered velocity vectors, NicheNet ligand database, identify ligands responsible velocity vectors. function first calls wrapper scvelo's recover_dynamics function, obtaining gene-wise velocity dynamics cluster. Folloewd Entrain ligand analysis. Note velocity clusters generated velocity data (.e. time derivative expression), rather expression data like typical usual cell clustering workflow Seurat FindClusters. wishing run pre-generated clusters (E.g. bespoke set marker genes) can inputting anndata custom cluster annotations anndata.obs metadata, passing column name cluster_key quite recommended cells similar expression exhibit different velocities. turn, input noisy dataset Entrain's randomForest, ligands come analysis spurious.

title: Identify ligands responsible for observed velocity vectors. — entrain_velocity
code: entrain_velocity(   receiver_obj,   sender_obj = NULL,   adata,   expressed_ligands = NULL,   sender_cluster_key = NULL,   sender_clusters = NULL,   reduction_key = NULL,   save_adata = NULL,   velocity_cluster_key = NULL,   num_jobs = 10L,   num_top_genes = NULL,   expression_proportion_cutoff = 0.1,   lr_network = NULL,   ligand_target_matrix = NULL,   ... )

title: Identify ligands responsible for observed velocity vectors. — entrain_velocity
text: save_adata Optional. Filename anndata object write results . given NULL, anndata saved. Recommended want re-run continue analysis scanpy/scvelo. velocity_cluster_key Column name cluster labels metadata adata_clustered. Can calculated manually scvelo scvelo.tl.velocity_clusters(). lr_network NicheNet ligand-receptor pairs data file. ligand_target_matrix NicheNet ligand-target data file. obj seurat object adata_clustered anndata file containing velocities, preclustered cluster_velocities(). n_jobs Long integer. Number parallel jobs run scvelo recover dynamics function. n_top_genes Long integer. Number top velocity genes calculate likelihoods . Default 500L. resolution Optional argument defining resolution velocity clustering. Default 0.05.

title: Identify ligands responsible for observed velocity vectors. — entrain_velocity
text: 'Seurat object ligand velocity results obj$misc$entrain$velocity_result.

text: ident Name cluster identity/identities cells seurat_obj Single-cell expression dataset Seurat object https://satijalab.org/seurat/. pct consider genes expressed expressed least specific fraction cells cluster. number indicates fraction. Default: 0.10. Choice parameter important depends largely used sequencing platform. recommend require lower fraction (like default 0.10) 10X data e.g. Smart-seq2 data. assay_oi wanted: specify assay look . Default value NULL consequence 'advanced' assay used define expressed genes.

title: NicheNetR function to determine expressed genes of a cell type from a Seurat object single-cell RNA seq dataset or Seurat spatial transcriptomics dataset — get_expressed_genes
text: character vector gene symbols expressed genes

title: Core function for Entrain ligand assignment that is agnostic to the trajectory inference algorithm used. — get_path_ligands
text: obj seurat object  cell pseudotimes contained metadata column column name pseudotime_key. expressed_ligands Character vector active ligands dataset (must rownames(obj)) lr_network NicheNet ligand-receptor pairs data file. ligand_target_matrix NicheNet ligand-target data file. path_cell_names vector cell names (must colnames(obj)), defining cells trajectory path associated ligands calculated. pseudotime_key Column name colnames(obj@meta.data) contains cell pseudotime values. cluster_key Column name colnames(obj@meta.data) corresponding return_model TRUE, additionally save raw random forest object obj@misc$entrain$paths$path_name$model

title: Core function for Entrain ligand assignment that is agnostic to the trajectory inference algorithm used. — get_path_ligands

what: Identify ligands responsible for trajectory dynamics using Monocle graph learning. — get_traj_ligands_monocle
title: Identify ligands responsible for trajectory dynamics using Monocle graph learning. — get_traj_ligands_monocle
text: Runs standard Monocle3 trajectory reconstruction pipeline, followed Entrain identify ligands responsible trajectory dynamics.

title: Identify ligands responsible for trajectory dynamics using Monocle graph learning. — get_traj_ligands_monocle
code: get_traj_ligands_monocle(   obj,   sender_obj = NULL,   sender_cluster_key = NULL,   sender_cluster_names = NULL,   num_dim = 10,   root_cells = NULL,   root_pr_nodes = NULL,   expressed_ligands = NULL,   path_cell_names = NULL,   path_nodes = NULL,   minimal_branch_len = 5,   ncenter = 50,   use_partition = TRUE,   precomputed_umap = NULL,   prune_graph = T,   close_loop = F,   overwrite = FALSE,   cds = NULL,   reduction_key = "MonocleUMAP_",   sender_reduction_key = "umap",   expression_proportion_cutoff = 0.01,   covariance_cutoff = 0.05,   lr_network,   ligand_target_matrix,   export_cds = TRUE )

title: Identify ligands responsible for trajectory dynamics using Monocle graph learning. — get_traj_ligands_monocle
text: obj seurat object containing receiver cells undergoing trajectory sender_obj seurat obj containing sender cells expressing ligands. Set NULL sender cells contained 'obj'. sender_cluster_key Column name metadata denotes sender cells specified. NULL, defaults default Seurat Idents given levels(obj) sender_cluster_names Unique values column sender_cluster_key denote sender cell clusters. num_dim Number dimensions monocle reduce_dimension function. root_cells Optional. Character vector root cell names comprise beginning trajectory (must colnames(obj)). given NULL, open window interactively select root cell (Monocle's default behaviour). expressed_ligands Character vector active ligands dataset (must rownames(obj)) path_cell_names Optional. Character vector cell names comprise differentiation trajectory analyzed Entrain (must colnames(obj)). given NULL, open window interactively select trajectory path analyze (Monocle's default behaviour). ncenter Parameter Monocle graph learning. use_partition Parameter Monocle graph learning precomputed_umap precomputed UMAP receiver cells wish build monocle trajectory , set name precomputed embedding e.g. precomputed_umap = 'umap' prune_graph Parameter Monocle graph learning. close_loop Parameter Monocle graph learning. overwrite existing Monocle trajectory obj (e.g. run function ), overwrite = TRUE delete old trajectory. Otherwise, old trajectory used Entrain. sender_reduction_key applicable sender_obj NULL: dimension reduction key sender_obj wish use, lr_network NicheNet ligand-receptor pairs data file. ligand_target_matrix NicheNet ligand-target data file. export_cds TRUE, saves Monocle cell_data_set trajectory object obj@misc$monocle_graph. Set TRUE want plot Entrain results afterwards.

title: Identify ligands responsible for trajectory dynamics using Monocle graph learning. — get_traj_ligands_monocle
text: Seurat object ligand velocity results obj$misc$entrain$velocity_result.

Must entrain_velocity run . velocity_clusters Values adata.obs.velocity_cluster_key denoting velocity clusters visualize. sender influences represent contribution towards velocity cluster , velocities dataset. velocity_cluster_key Column name adata.obs metadata denoting velocity clusters. frameon scvelo.pl.velocity_embedding argument: Draws frame around plot. size scvelo.pl.velocity_embedding argument: Size points. sender_palette matplotlib colorscale. title Plot title. filename Filename plot save.

title: Plots a heatmap of ligand-target regulatory potentials extracted from NicheNet. — plot_velocity_ligand_targets
text: obj seurat object analyzed entrain_velocity n_top_targets Number top likelihood target genes visualize. Default 10. n_top_ligands Number top ligands visualize. Default 10. ligand_target_matrix NicheNet ligand-target data file. color_low Hex code lower limit color_high Hex code upper limit.

what: Plot top ligands overlayed on a RNA velocity plot — plot_velocity_ligands
title: Plot top ligands overlayed on a RNA velocity plot — plot_velocity_ligands
text: Visualizes ligands likely driving observed RNA velocities.

title: Plot top ligands overlayed on a RNA velocity plot — plot_velocity_ligands
code: plot_velocity_ligands(   adata,   color = "dimgrey",   alpha = 0.1,   density = 3,   arrow_size = 1,   linewidth_scale = 2,   vector_type = "stream",   velocity_cluster_key = "vcluster",   cell_palette = "dimgrey",   size = 100,   velocity_cluster_palette = "gnuplot",   label_fontsize = 15,   top_n_ligands = 5L,   figsize = c(10, 10),   plot_output_path = "entrain_velocity_ligands.png" )

title: Plot top ligands overlayed on a RNA velocity plot — plot_velocity_ligands
text: adata Path .h5ad anndata object. Must entrain_velocity run . color scvelo.pl argument: Key annotations observations/cells variables/genes. Use want dot color denote cell type annotation. Default dimgrey, annotation colors. alpha Opacity points. density Density RNA velocity vectors. arrow_size Size RNA velocity vector arrowhead. linewidth_scale Width RNA velocity vector body. vector_type Whether plot scvelo.pl.velocity_embedding_stream() plot scvelo.pl.velocity_embedding_grid() plot. Default stream velocity_cluster_key Column name adata.obs metadata denoting velocity clusters. cell_palette matplotlib color palette annotations denoted argument color. size scvelo.pl.velocity_embedding argument: Size points. velocity_cluster_palette matplotlib color palette denoting colorscale velocity clusters. label_fontsize Font size ligand labels top_n_ligands Number top ligands include label. figsize Figure size. Default c(10,10) plot_output_path Filename plot save. velocity_clusters Values adata.obs.velocity_cluster_key denoting velocity clusters ligands visualize.

title: Plot top ligands overlayed on a RNA velocity plot — plot_velocity_ligands
text: NULL. Saves plot working directory name plot_output_path
